head.title: Rational Design of a Redox-Active Nonaqueous Electrolyte for a High-Energy-Density Supercapacitor Based on Carbon Nanotubes | ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

meta.content: Rational Design of a Redox-Active Nonaqueous Electrolyte for a High-Energy-Density Supercapacitor Based on Carbon Nanotubes

A redox-active electrolyte supercapacitor (RAES) is a promising system that increases the energy density of a supercapacitor by providing additional pseudocapacitance, which arises from an inserted redox couple in an electrolyte. However, the energy density of RAESs is still considerably low for practical applications, and enhancing the operating voltage window as well as the capacitance of RAESs is very necessary. In this study, we rationally designed a nonaqueous redox-active electrolyte mainly on the basis of the relative position of the electrochemical stability window of a supporting electrolyte and the redox potential of a redox couple. Therefore, the judicious combination of a redox pair, decamethylcobaltocene/decamethylcobaltocenium, and a supporting electrolyte, 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide dissolved in adiponitrile, not only provides additional capacitance from a faradaic redox reaction (21.3 → 57.1 F g–1) but also extends the operating voltage window to almost the entire electrochemical stability window of the supporting electrolyte (3.1 V). A carbon-nanotube-based RAES exhibits outstanding performance, including improved energy density (75.6 Wh kg–1), compared to previously reported nonaqueous RAESs. Our systematic approach might play a crucial role in the further development of high-performance nonaqueous RAESs.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

span.p: A rationally designed redox-active electrolyte exploits the entire electrochemical stability window of a supporting electrolyte and paves the way to a high energy density supercapacitor.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Supercapacitors are intriguing energy-storage devices equipped with fast energy delivery and excellent cycle stability.
(1,2)
The high-power characteristic, which originates from the rapid electrostatic charge accumulation at the interface of the carbon-based electrode and the electrolyte, is highly desirable for applications such as regenerative braking systems in electric vehicles,
(3)
consumer electronics,
(4)
and power grid applications.
(5)
In contrast, the energy densities of supercapacitors are lower than those of other energy storage devices, such as batteries, because the charge is confined to the carbon electrode/electrolyte interface.
(3,6)
To meet the increasing energy demand for practical application of supercapacitors, researchers have been striving to improve the capacitance (
C
) and voltage window (
V
) based on the equation of energy density (
E
=
CV
2
/2).
(7,8)

The most common approaches for energy-density enhancement of supercapacitors are based on the modification of their electrodes.
(9−11)
The additional capacitance can be obtained by using pseudocapacitive materials as electrodes (e.g., transition metal oxides and electrically conducting polymers)
(11−13)
or intentionally introducing surface functionalities (e.g., oxygen) on carbon electrodes.
(14−16)
However, the surface-limited charge storage of pseudocapacitive materials and the instability of surface moieties often result in a considerably lower capacitance than theoretical values (a few thousand farads per gram) and the deterioration of the enhanced capacitance in long-term cycling, respectively.
(1,2,13,16,17)
On the other hand, to expand the voltage window, asymmetric electrode configurations consisting of carbon-based materials and pseudocapacitive materials have been extensively studied.
(18,19)
The difference in the material properties of carbon and pseudocapacitive electrodes leads to disparate optimal operating voltage ranges, which can extend the cell voltage window beyond the thermodynamic limit of aqueous electrolytes, 1.23 V.
(19,20)
While the cell voltage enhancement has been mostly derived from the electrode component, the electrolyte is another important contributing factor to be considered in the energy-density enhancement of supercapacitors.

Recently, a redox-active electrolyte containing a redox couple in a supporting electrolyte has been considered as a promising alternative to the above-mentioned examples in order to achieve high-energy-density supercapacitors.
(21−26)
The incorporated redox-active compounds provide a high pseudocapacitance from the redox reaction occurring at the interface of a carbon electrode and an electrolyte. Several redox couples, such as potassium iodide,
(21)
hydroquinone,
(22,23)
cupric chloride,
(24)
and potassium ferricyanide,
(25)
incorporated in aqueous electrolytes have resulted in significant increases in electrode capacitances. Moreover, it has been demonstrated that the combination of redox-active electrolytes with pseudocapacitive materials
(27,28)
or the introduction of dual redox-active electrolytes
(29,30)
could lead to a further increase in their capacitances. However, water-based supporting electrolytes intrinsically constrain the operating voltage window to ∼1 V, which limits their energy density enhancement.

To overcome this limitation, several studies have been conducted on nonaqueous redox-active electrolyte supercapacitors (RAESs).
(26,31−42)
In the early stage of the research, some of the nonaqueous RAESs exhibited narrow cell voltage windows (∼2 V) compared to commercial supercapacitors with nonaqueous electrolytes (∼2.5 V).
(31,32,36,37)
Recently developed RAESs have exhibited cell voltage windows comparable to those of commercial ones (∼2.5 V), but these windows lead to only moderate enhancement in their energy densities.
(33,34,39,40)
A relatively wide cell voltage window (>2.5 V) has also been demonstrated; however, the criterion for the electrochemical stability window was loosely defined or the cell was operated at a high temperature (60 °C) due to the high viscosity of the electrolyte.
(35,38,41,42)
Recently, our research group suggested a systematic approach for developing high-energy-density RAESs.
(26)
By incorporating a redox couple, whose redox potential is located near the positive end of the stability window of supporting electrolytes, the energy density can be enhanced via the increased capacitance and cell voltage. Although the demonstration was successful and considered to be reasonable, the cell voltage of the RAES was very low (2.1 V). Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop high-voltage RAESs on the basis of this systematic approach.

In this study, we demonstrate that the energy density of carbon-nanotube-based supercapacitors can be highly enhanced with careful selection of redox species (decamethylcobaltocene, DmCc) in a nonaqueous supporting electrolyte (1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide dissolved in adiponitrile). The DmCc/DmCc
+
has been chosen on the basis of its redox potential, solubility, charge-transfer rate, and electrochemical stability. As the voltage plateau of the DmCc/DmCc
+
redox couple (−1.77 V vs Ag/Ag
+
) is near the negative limit of the electrochemical stability window (−1.9 V vs Ag/Ag
+
) of the supporting electrolyte, the RAES can operate in almost the entire electrochemical stability window of the supporting electrolyte (∼3.3 V). The incorporation of DmCc/DmCc
+
improves not only the operating voltage window (2.6 → 3.1 V) but also the capacitance (21.3 → 57.1 F g
–1
at 0.5 A g
–1
), which leads to excellent energy performance (75.6 Wh kg
–1
at 0.5 A g
–1
). In addition, the RAES with DmCc/DmCc
+
exhibits excellent cycle stability (98.8% over 8000 cycles) possibly because of the stable molecular structure of DmCc/DmCc
+
. This work may lay an important foundation for the development of high-energy-density nonaqueous RAESs.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: Preparation of the Redox-Active Electrolyte and CNT Electrode
div.div:
A redox pair, decamethylcobaltocene (DmCc, Sigma-Aldrich) and decamethylcobaltocenium hexafluorophosphate (DmCcPF
6
, 98%, Alfa-Aesar), was added together into the mixture of 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide (EMImTFSI, water content = 27.5 ppm, C-TRI) and adiponitrile (ADN, > 99%, packaged under argon in resealable ChemSeal bottles, Alfa-Aesar). The solution was stirred with a magnetic bar for 30 min. The ADN solvent was treated with molecular sieves (3 Å, Sigma-Aldrich) prior to use. The preparation process was conducted in a glovebox (water and oxygen <1 ppm). For the electrode preparation, single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs,
d
= 0.7–1.4 nm, Sigma-Aldrich) were dispersed in propylene carbonate (Sigma-Aldrich) with tip sonication (Sonics & Materials, VC 750) for 1 h. The as-prepared SWNT solution was drop-casted onto a carbon paper (CP, Toray Industries, Inc., TGP-H-090) and dried on a hot plate (250 °C). The mass of the SWNT electrode is 0.4 mg cm
–2
. Additionally, the end of the CP was attached to a titanium foil (thickness = 0.032 mm, 99.7%, Alfa-Aesar) by using carbon paste (CSP-3225, Chang Sung Corp.) to avoid the contact between the gold clip from the electrochemical analyzer and the electrolyte ascending along the porous CP during long-term measurements. The hardening of carbon paste was performed on a hot plate (150 °C) for more than 3 h. Surface morphologies of the SWNT electrode and CP current collector were investigated using a field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, S-4800, Hitachi). The chemical properties of SWNT were characterized with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI 5000 VersaProbe, ULVAC-PHI) and Raman spectroscopy (LabRAM ARAMIS IR
2
, Horiba Jobin Yvon, 532 nm laser).

div.h3: Fabrication and Electrochemical Characterization of Redox-Active Electrolyte Supercapacitors
div.div:
The electrochemical cells were fabricated in an argon-filled glovebox. A poly(tetrafluoroethylene) separator (PTFE, thickness ∼65 μm and pore size ∼0.2 μm, Millipore) was placed between two symmetrical SWNT electrodes and wrapped with Teflon sealing tape. The assembly was submerged in the redox-active electrolyte (4.6 mL, 0.04 M DmCc, 0.08 M DmCcPF
6
, and 0.5 M EMImTFSI in ADN) and hermetically sealed in a glass container. Prior to the electrochemical tests, the conditioning process was performed to attain a stable redox reaction (
Figure S1
). To investigate the electrochemical properties, galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD), cyclic voltammetry (CV), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were conducted with an electrochemical analyzer (BioLogic, VSP-300) in a two-electrode configuration, unless otherwise noted. In the EIS measurement, the SWNT electrode was used without titanium foil attached to provide a better understanding of the charge-transfer process at the interface of the SWNT electrode and the redox-active electrolyte. The EIS was measured with a 10 mV AC signal in the frequency range from 0.01 to 10
6
Hz. The voltage trace of each electrode during GCD was displayed with respect to the Ag/Ag
+
reference electrode (containing the filling solution of 0.1 M EMImTFSI and 0.01 M AgNO
3
in ADN, −0.08 V vs Fc/Fc
+
= 0.544 V vs standard hydrogen electrode,
Figure S2
). All of the equations used in the electrochemical characterization are provided as
Supporting Information
.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
A RAES composed of SWNT electrodes, CP current collectors, and a PTFE separator is immersed in a redox-active electrolyte consisting of a DmCc/DmCcPF
6
redox pair and an EMImTFSI/ADN supporting electrolyte (
Figure
1
). The randomly entangled SWNT bundles and interwoven carbon fibers of CP structures were clearly observed in SEM images (
Figures
1
a,b). The SWNT was chosen as an electrode because of its high chemical stability, which minimizes any possible confusion from unwanted reactions between surface functionalities of other carbon materials and a redox couple.
(43,44)
The SWNT surface exhibits low oxygen content (<5%) and high sp
2
/sp
3
ratio (= 7.5) as revealed by XPS survey and C 1s scan spectra, respectively (
Figures
1
e,f). Furthermore, the Raman spectrum of the SWNT clearly shows radial breathing mode (RBM) peaks between 100–300 cm
–1
, a very strong G-band (∼1581 cm
–1
), a weak D-band (∼1330 cm
–1
), and a well-defined 2D band (∼2648 cm
–1
) (
Figure
1
g). This indicates that the SWNT consists mainly of graphitic carbons with a tubular structure.
(45,46)
Both DmCc and DmCc
+
were employed as redox species and dissolved into an EMImTFSI/ADN supporting electrolyte (
Figure
1
d). A DmCc/DmCc
+
redox pair is one of the permethylated transition-metal sandwich complexes and exhibits highly negative redox potential (−1.73 V vs Ag/Ag
+
,
Figure S1
). The reversible redox reaction of DmCc/DmCc
+
occurs at the interface of the SWNT electrode/electrolyte during the charging/discharging process according to the following equation:

The electrochemical stability window of EMImTFSI/ADN in our system was determined to be 3.3 V by CV measurement in a three-electrode configuration (
Figure
2
). The evaluation criterion of anodic and cathodic limits was established on the basis of the rate of the slope change (d
2
I
/d
V
2
< 3) in CV curves measured over the extended voltage ranges (
Supporting Information
). When the positive voltage range extends wider than 1.4 V, the rate of the slope change (d
2
I
/d
V
2
) sharply increases from 2.6 to 96.7, which corresponds to the oxidation of the TFSI
–
anion in the supporting electrolyte. In the negative voltage region, the CV curves show relatively moderate changes in their slope (d
I
/d
V
) compared to the positive side. However, the rate of slope change (d
2
I
/d
V
2
) starts to exhibit a steep incline when the voltage approaches −2.0 V (d
2
I
/d
V
2
= 3.69), which corresponds to the reduction of ADN decomposition. The potential ends are in good agreement with the values reported in previous studies.
(47,48)
On the basis of this evaluation, the stable electrochemical voltage window was determined to range from −1.9 to 1.4 V vs Ag/Ag
+
(total of 3.3 V,
Figure
2
).

The cell voltage of the electrical double layer capacitor (EDLC) (without DmCc/DmCc
+
redox couple) was restricted to 2.6 V (
Figure
3
a). The GCD graph of EDLC clearly shows a typical triangular shape in both positive and negative electrodes. From the rest potential of 0.22 V (vs Ag/Ag
+
) as a starting point, the symmetric voltage profiles of each electrode were observed in the range of 0.22 to 1.37 V (vs Ag/Ag
+
) at the positive electrode and 0.22 to −1.23 V (vs Ag/Ag
+
) at the negative electrode. The slight deviation from the symmetric voltage distribution would be explained with the difference in the double-layer structures pertaining to the ions (EMIm
+
vs TFSI
–
) and/or any dissimilarity inadvertently introduced into the electrodes.
(49)
In this case, the electrochemical stability window of EMImTFSI/ADN (3.3 V) cannot be fully exploited because the cell voltage is restricted by the positive electrode limit over which TFSI
–
oxidation can occur (1.4 V vs Ag/Ag
+
). Due to symmetry, this also limits the negative electrode span (>−1.23 V). Therefore, the symmetric EDLC operation leaves a wide range of unexploited voltage (∼0.7 V) between the negative electrode limit and the negative background limit of the supporting electrolyte (ADN decomposition).

div.p:
Figure 3. Galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) curves with the voltage profiles of positive and negative electrodes in (a) EMImTFSI/ADN and (b) DmCc/DmCc
+
/EMImTFSI/ADN, measured at a current density of 2.5 A g
–1
. (c) Cyclic voltammetry curves of each electrolyte solution (
v
= 50 mV s
–1
).

div.div:
The introduction of DmCc/DmCc
+
increases the cell voltage to 3.1 V by generating an asymmetric electrode voltage distribution (
Figure
3
b). This enables the usage of the voltage range, which cannot be accessed by symmetric EDLC supercapacitors. The concentrations of DmCc and DmCc
+
were 0.04 and 0.08 M, respectively. Concentrations outside of the ideal range can cause solubility and stability problems. (
Figure S3
). The GCD curve with a redox couple exhibits completely asymmetric voltage profiles, including a typical triangular curve and a plateau at the positive and negative electrode, respectively. The positive electrode represents EDLC-like behavior with extensive voltage variation from −1.71 to 1.33 V vs Ag/Ag
+
. Since most of the cell potential is applied to the positive electrode, the cell potential can be increased until the positive electrode reaches the positive background limit of the supporting electrolyte. In contrast, the voltage of negative electrode is almost constant, with only a slight variation between −1.71 and −1.77 V vs Ag/Ag
+
, which is a battery-like behavior. As the amount of accumulated charge (
Q
=
CV
) must be equal in each electrode, a considerably higher negative electrode than positive electrode capacitance (2095.0 vs 34.1 mF at 2.5 A g
–1
) leads to the formation of a voltage plateau. The position of the voltage plateau at the negative electrode corresponds well with the redox potential of DmCc/DmCc
+
at −1.73 V vs Ag/Ag
+
(
Figure S1
), which suggests that the redox reaction occurs at the negative electrode. The mass of the active redox species can be estimated using the GCD curve by calculating the amount of charge (
Q
=
CV
) involved and was determined to be ∼0.6 mg (
Figure S4
). In particular, the voltage plateau from DmCc/DmCc
+
is so near the negative limit of the supporting electrolyte (−1.9 V vs Ag/Ag
+
, ADN decomposition) that the RAES can exploit most of the unused potential region by EDLCs. Therefore, the operating cell voltage window of RAES can be much wider than that of an EDLC without a redox couple (2.6 → 3.1 V). Altogether, the DmCc/DmCc
+
performs as a very suitable redox couple for extending the cell voltage window of supercapacitors with the EMImTFSI/ADN supporting electrolyte.

The supercapacitor with DmCc/DmCc
+
not only extends the cell voltage window but also increases the cell capacitance due to the additional faradaic redox reaction (18.0 → 41.9 F g
–1
at 2.5 A g
–1
). At the positive electrode where the electric double layer is formed, no significant difference is observed in the capacitance, regardless of the presence of DmCc/DmCc
+
(78.8 vs 85.2 F g
–1
at 2.5 A g
–1
). On the other hand, the capacitance at negative electrode shows an approximately 80-fold increase with the insertion of DmCc/DmCc
+
, which can be ascribed to the pseudocapacitance arising from the redox reaction at the negative SWNT/electrolyte interface (66.0 vs 5237 F g
–1
at 2.5 A g
–1
). This huge capacitance enhancement at the negative electrode leads to a cell capacitance more than twice as high (18.0 → 41.9 F g
–1
at 2.5 A g
–1
). We also confirmed the pronounced capacitance enhancement from the CV measurement (19.5 → 42.3 F g
–1
), in which the cell capacitance is proportional to the CV integrated area (
Figure
3
c). As a result, the proper insertion of the redox couple triggers a simultaneous enhancement in cell capacitance and operation voltage window, providing more than 3-fold higher energy density,
E
cell
(16.3 → 53.1 Wh kg
–1
at 2.5 A g
–1
), with a similar level of power density,
P
cell
(3.19 → 3.13 kW kg
–1
at 2.5 A g
–1
).
Table
1
lists the detailed information for the cell and electrode, including mass, capacitance, operation voltage window, energy, and power densities derived from GCD curves.

Table 1. Mass, Operating Voltage Window, Capacitances of Electrode and Cell, Specific Cell Capacitance, Energy, and Power Densities of Supercapacitors with and without DmCc/DmCc
+
in EMImTFSI/ADN (
I
= 2.5 A g
–1
)

The cell incorporating with the redox couple shows reasonable rate capability.
Figure
4
a exhibits the variation of cell capacitance (
C
cell
) with increasing current density. Incorporation of DmCc/DmCc
+
shows improved
C
cell
values in all current densities measured (0.5–20 A g
–1
). At a current density of 0.5 A g
–1
, the
C
cell
with DmCc/DmCc
+
was approximately 3-fold higher than that of EDLC (57.1 vs 21.3 F g
–1
). Even at a high current density of 10 A g
–1
, a
C
cell
enhancement of 1.5-fold was still retained (24.1 vs 16.5 F g
–1
). As the current density increases, however, the
C
cell
enhancement attained from the DmCc/DmCc
+
redox reaction gradually decreases. The behavior can be mainly ascribed to the slow ion diffusion in the nonaqueous redox-active electrolyte. This slow ion diffusion is caused by the high viscosity arising from the additional insertion of DmCc/DmCc
+
(
Figure
4
b).
(31,32,39)

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) Cell capacitance vs current density plots, (b) Nyquist plots, and (c) Ragone plots with/without DmCc/DmCc
+
in EMImTFSI/ADN.

div.div:
The inclusion of DmCc/DmCc
+
also changed the Nyquist plot due to the pseudocapacitance from the redox chemical reaction (
Figure
4
b). In the high-frequency region, Nyquist plots of the supercapacitors with and without the redox couple exhibited comparable equivalent series resistance (ESR) values of 9.6 and 10.2 Ω, respectively (see the inset in
Figure
4
b). Meanwhile, no semicircle was observed in either Nyquist plot, which implies the fast-charge-transfer process of the DmCc/DmCc
+
redox reaction at the electrode/electrolyte interface. In the middle frequency region, the electrolyte with DmCc/DmCc
+
exhibits a longer 45° Warburg region than that without DmCc/DmCc
+
, indicating that the insertion of DmCc/DmCc
+
results in lower ion diffusion efficiency.
(50−52)
As a sufficient concentration of DmCc/DmCc
+
is highly required for its stable redox reaction, the redox-active electrolyte was almost saturated and more viscous than the electrolyte without redox species. Therefore, the increased viscosity from the additional DmCc/DmCc
+
leads to the slow diffusion of the redox-active electrolyte.
(53)
In the low frequency region, the Nyquist plot without redox couple displayed a near vertical line (∼85° from
x
-axis) as typical EDLC behavior but that with DmCc/DmCc
+
presented a slight deviation from the parallel line (∼75° from
x
-axis), which is ascribed to the DmCc/DmCc
+
redox reaction.
(54)
Notably, the titanium foil attached to the SWNT/CP electrode/current collector was not used for this EIS measurement because the contact resistance between them could have obstructed a clear understanding of the charge-transfer process at the electrode/electrolyte interface. The permeation of solution into the CP is not significant in the short time period required for the EIS measurement.

The Ragone plot of the supercapacitor including the DmCc/DmCc
+
redox couple displays a significant energy density enhancement without noticeable degradation in power characteristics (
Figure
4
c). The energy and power densities were calculated based on the integrated area under the galvanostatic discharge curves for precise evaluation of nonlinear GCD characteristics (
Supporting Information
).
(24,55)
The RAES with DmCc/DmCc
+
represents the enhancement in both
C
cell
(21.3 → 57.1 F g
–1
) and operation voltage window (2.6 → 3.1 V), resulting in an approximately 4-fold higher
E
cell
(19.9 → 75.6 Wh kg
–1
at 0.5 A g
–1
) while maintaining the power performance (0.63 → 0.53 kW kg
–1
at 0.5 A g
–1
). The
E
cell
presented in this work (75.6 Wh kg
–1
) is one of the highest values reported so far with nonaqueous RAESs (
Table
2
). The large enhancement in energy density of our redox supercapacitor is based mainly on the careful consideration of the relationship between the electrochemical stability limits of the supporting electrolyte and the location of the redox potential of the redox species.

div.div:
Finally, the RAES with DmCc/DmCc
+
represents excellent long-term cycle stability. The cycle stability was measured by a GCD test after the cell was stabilized. It was performed during 8000 charge–discharge cycles at 5 A g
–1
and showed remarkably high
C
cell
retention (98.8% over 8000 cycles), which is comparable to the RAES without DmCc/DmCc
+
(95.9% over 8000 cycles;
Figure
5
a). Moreover, the voltage profiles of each electrode were maintained within the electrochemical stability window of the supporting electrolyte and were well-preserved with repeated charge–discharge cycles. Negligible changes in
iR
drops (0.15 → 0.20 V) were observed (
Figures
5
b,c and
S5
). The DmCc/DmCc
+
redox couple exhibits high reversibility and electrochemical stability over a wide operating voltage window, possibly because of a stable molecular structure. The permethylated cyclopentadienyl rings in DmCc/DmCc
+
could prevent not only the unwanted interaction between the cobalt center and surrounding chemicals but also the shift of the redox potential, which might have ensured the long-lasting stable redox reaction during cell operation.
(56−58)

A review. Electrochem. capacitors, also called supercapacitors, store energy using either ion adsorption (electrochem. double layer capacitors) or fast surface redox reactions (pseudo-capacitors). A notable improvement in performance has been achieved through recent advances in understanding charge storage mechanisms and the development of advanced nanostructured materials. The discovery that ion desolvation occurs in pores smaller than the solvated ions has led to higher capacitance for electrochem. double layer capacitors using carbon electrodes with sub-nanometer pores, and opened the door to designing high-energy d. devices using a variety of electrolytes. Combination of pseudo-capacitive nanomaterials, including oxides, nitrides and polymers, with the latest generation of nanostructured lithium electrodes has brought the energy d. of electrochem. capacitors closer to that of batteries. The use of carbon nanotubes has further advanced micro-electrochem. capacitors, enabling flexible and adaptable devices to be made. Math. modeling and simulation will be the key to success in designing tomorrow's high-energy and high-power devices.

A review with 50 refs. Electrochem. capacitors (EC) also called "supercapacitors" or "ultracapacitors" store the energy in the elec. field of the electrochem. double-layer. Use of high surface-area electrodes result in extremely large capacitance. Single cell voltage of ECs is typically limited to 1-3 V depending on the electrolyte used. Small electrochem. capacitors for low-voltage electronic applications have been com. available for many years. Different applications demanding large ECs with high voltage and improved energy and power d. are under discussion. Fundamental principles, performance, characteristics, present and future applications of electrochem. capacitors are presented in this communication.

The science and technol. of ultracapacitors are reviewed, with 24 refs., for a no. of electrode materials, including carbon, mixed metal oxides, and conducting polymers. More work has been done using microporous carbons than with the other materials and most of the com. available devices use carbon electrodes and an org. electrolytes. The energy d. of these devices is 3-5 Wh/kg with a power d. of 300-500 W/kg for high efficiency (90-95%) charge/discharges. Projections of future developments using carbon indicate that energy densities of 10 Wh/kg or higher are likely with power densities of 1-2 kW/kg. A key problem in the fabrication of these advanced devices is the bonding of the thin electrodes to a current collector such that the contact resistance is less than 0.1 Ω cm2. Special attention is given in the paper to comparing the power d. characteristics of ultracapacitors and batteries. The comparisons should be made at the same charge/discharge efficiency.

A review. The increasing interest in energy storage for the grid can be attributed to multiple factors, including the capital costs of managing peak demands, the investments needed for grid reliability, and the integration of renewable energy sources. Although existing energy storage is dominated by pumped hydroelec., there is the recognition that battery systems can offer a no. of high-value opportunities, provided that lower costs can be obtained. The battery systems reviewed here include sodium-sulfur batteries that are com. available for grid applications, redox-flow batteries that offer low cost, and lithium-ion batteries whose development for com. electronics and elec. vehicles is being applied to grid storage.

A review. Supercapacitors are currently attracting intensive attention because they can provide energy d. by orders of magnitude higher than dielec. capacitors, greater power d., and longer cycling ability than batteries. The main challenge for supercapacitors is to develop them with high energy d. that is close to that of a current rechargeable battery, while maintaining their inherent characteristics of high power and long cycling life. Consequently, much research has been devoted to enhance the performance of supercapacitors by either maximizing the specific capacitance and/or increasing the cell voltage. The latest advances in the exploration and development of new supercapacitor systems and related electrode materials are highlighted. Also, the prospects and challenges in practical application are analyzed, aiming to give deep insights into the material science and electrochem. fields.

A review. In recent years, tremendous research effort has been aimed at increasing the energy d. of supercapacitors without sacrificing high power capability so that they reach the levels achieved in batteries and at lowering fabrication costs. For this purpose, two important problems have to be solved: first, it is crit. to develop ways to design high performance electrode materials for supercapacitors; second, it is necessary to achieve controllably assembled supercapacitor types (such as sym. capacitors including double-layer and pseudo-capacitors, asym. capacitors, and Li-ion capacitors). The explosive growth of research in this field makes this review timely. Recent progress in the research and development of high performance electrode materials and high-energy supercapacitors is summarized. Several key issues for improving the energy densities of supercapacitors and some mutual relationships among various effecting parameters are reviewed, and challenges and perspectives in this exciting field are also discussed. This provides fundamental insight into supercapacitors and offers an important guideline for future design of advanced next-generation supercapacitors for industrial and consumer applications.

A review. Currently, supercapacitors (SCs) are a promising field in the area of energy storage devices. In the last few decades, different types of C based materials with suitable surface modifications, metal oxides, metal hydroxides, conducting polymers and their various composites have been used as electrodes to improve the energy performance of SCs. Different technologies like asym. and hybrid systems have also been introduced. Another alternative approach was proposed recently by a few research groups, wherein electrolytes (liq. and polymer) can enhance the performance of the SCs via redox reactions at the electrode-electrolyte interface, by introducing redox additives or mediators in the electrolytes. The main advantage of this new technique is its simple and safe prepn. method, along with cost effectiveness compared to the prepn. of some active electrode materials. Hence it is believed that identification of suitable redox additives or species in electrolytes will be of interest in the field of SCs in the coming years.

A review. Most methods for improving supercapacitor performance are based on developments of electrode materials to optimally exploit their storage mechanisms, namely elec. double layer capacitance and pseudocapacitance. In such cases, the electrolyte is supposed to be electrochem. as inert as possible so that a wide potential window can be achieved. Interestingly, in recent years, there has been a growing interest in the investigation of supercapacitors with an electrolyte that can offer redox activity. Such redox electrolytes have been shown to offer increased charge storage capacity, and possibly other benefits. There are however some confusions, for example, on the nature of contributions of the redox electrolyte to the increased storage capacity in comparison with pseudocapacitance, or by expression of the overall increased charge storage capacity as capacitance. This report intends to provide a brief but crit. review on the pros and cons of the application of such redox electrolytes in supercapacitors, and to advocate development of the relevant research into a new electrochem. energy storage device in parallel with, but not the same as that of supercapacitors.

A review. Supercapacitors have attracted intense attention due to their great potential to meet the demand of both high energy d. and power d. in many advanced technologies. Various carbon-based nanocomposites are currently pursued as supercapacitor electrodes because of the synergistic effect between carbon (high power d.) and pseudo-capacitive nanomaterials (high energy d.). This feature article aims to review most recent progress on 3D (3D) carbon based nanostructures for advanced supercapacitor applications in view of their structural intertwinement which not only create the desired hierarchical porous channels, but also possess higher elec. cond. and better structural mech. stability. The carbon nanostructures comprise of CNTs-based networks, graphene-based architectures, hierarchical porous carbon-based nanostructures and other even more complex carbon-based 3D configurations. Their advantages and disadvantages are compared and summarized based on the results published in the literature. In addn., we also discuss and view the ongoing trends in materials development for advanced supercapacitors.

A review. Supercapacitor electrodes and devices that use conducting polymers are envisaged to bridge the gap between existing C-based supercapacitors and batteries to form units of intermediate specific energy. This review looks at the major conducting polymer materials, namely, polyaniline, polypyrrole, polythiophene and derivs. of polythiophene, as well as composites of these materials with C nanotubes and inorg. battery materials. Various treatments of the conducting polymer materials to improve their properties are considered and comparisons are made with other supercapacitor materials such as C and with inorg. battery materials. Conducting polymers are pseudo-capacitive materials, which means that the bulk of the material undergoes a fast redox reaction to provide the capacitive response and they exhibit superior specific energies to the C-based supercapacitors (double-layer capacitors). In general conducting polymers are more conductive than the inorg. battery materials and consequently have greater power capability. On the downside, conducting polymers swell and contract substantially on charge and discharge, resp. Consequently, cycle-life is poor compared with C-based supercapacitors which generally only charge via adsorption and desorption of (giving typically a few thousand cycles for conducting polymers compared with >500,000 cycles for C-based devices).

A review of recent advances in strategies for advanced metal oxide-based hybrid nanostructure design, with the focus on the binder-free film/array electrodes. Metal oxide nanostructures are promising electrode materials for lithium-ion batteries and supercapacitors because of their high specific capacity/capacitance, typically 2-3 times higher than that of the carbon/graphite-based materials. These binder-free electrodes, with the integration of unique merits of each component, can provide larger electrochem. active surface area, faster electron transport and superior ion diffusion, thus leading to substantially improved cycling and rate performance. However, their cycling stability and rate performance still cannot meet the requirements of practical applications. Several recently emerged concepts of using ordered nanostructure arrays, synergetic core-shell structures, nanostructured current collectors, and flexible paper/textile electrodes are highlighted, pointing out advantages and challenges where appropriate. Some future electrode design trends and directions are also discussed.

A review with 54 refs. The electrochem. storage of energy in various carbon materials (activated carbons, aerogels, xerogels, nanostructures) used as capacitor electrodes is considered. Different types of capacitors with a pure electrostatic attraction and/or pseudocapacitance effects are presented. Their performance in various electrolytes is studied taking into account the different range of operating voltage (1 V for aq. and 3 V for aprotic solns.). Trials are undertaken for estg. the role of micro and mesopores during charging the elec. double layer in both kinds of electrolytic solns. for which the elec. cond. and the size of solvated ions are different. The effect of pseudocapacitance for maximizing the total capacitance is esp. documented. Carbons chem. modified by a strong oxidn. treatment represent a very well defined region of pseudocapacitance properties due to the Faradaic redox reactions of their rich surface functionality. Conducting polymers (polyaniline, polypyrrole, polythiophene derivs.) and oxidized metallic particles (Ru, Mn, Co,...) deposited on the carbons also participate in the enhancement of the final capacity through fast faradaic pseudocapacitance effects. Evaluation of capacitor performance by different techniques, e.g. voltammetry, impedance spectroscopy, charge/discharge characteristics is also discussed.

We demonstrate the high performance of supercapacitors fabricated with vertically aligned carbon nanotubes and nonaq. electrolytes such as ionic liqs. and conventional org. electrolytes. Specific capacitance, max. power and energy d. of the supercapacitor measured in ionic liq. were ∼75 F g-1, ∼987 kW kg-1 and ∼27 W h kg-1, resp. The high power performance was consistently indicated by a fast relaxation time const. of 0.2 s. In addn., electrochem. oxidn. of the carbon nanotubes improved the specific capacitance (∼58 F g-1) and energy d. (∼53 W h kg-1). Both high power and energy d. could be attributed to the fast ion transport realized by the alignment of carbon nanotubes and the wide operational voltage defined by the ionic liq. The demonstrated carbon-nanotube- and nonaq.-electrolyte-based supercapacitors show great potential for the development of high-performance energy storage devices.

Compn. design and morphol. control can lead to high performance electrode materials for energy storage devices. In this work a graphene/porous Fe2O3 nanocomposite anode material is fabricated via a template-assisted nanocasting process. This nanocomposite consists of graphene scaffold with high electronic cond. and interconnected Fe2O3 with porous structure, thus exposing ample active sites for redox reactions and offering sufficient contacts with the electrolyte. Owing to these morphol. advantages, the nanocomposite outperforms nearly all the reported Fe-based anode materials by delivering a high specific capacitance of 1095 F g-1 at a c.d. of 3 A g-1. In addn., the material shows great rate capability and good cycling stability. Asym. supercapacitors are fabricated by assembling the graphene/porous Fe2O3 nanocomposite (as the anode material) with a CoNi-layered double hydroxide/carbon nanotube composite (as the cathode material). The devices exhibit high energy and power densities of 98.0 W h kg-1 and 22,826 W kg-1, which are among the best performances reported to date for asym. supercapacitors.

Three types of elec. conducting polymers (ECPs), i.e. polyaniline (PANI), polypyrrole (PPy) and poly-(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) were tested as supercapacitor electrode materials in the form of composites with multiwalled C nanotubes (CNTs). The energy storage in such a type of composite combines an electrostatic attraction as well as quick faradaic processes called pseudo-capacitance. C nanotubes play the role of a perfect backbone for a homogeneous distribution of ECP in the composite. It is well known that pure conducting polymers are mech. weak, hence, the carbon nanotubes preserve the ECP active material from mech. changes (shrinkage and breaking) during long cycling. Apart of excellent conducting and mech. properties, the presence of nanotubes improves also the charge transfer that enables a high charge/discharge rate. For an optimal use of ECPs in electrochem. capacitors, a special electrode compn. with ≈20 wt.% of CNTs and a careful selection of the potential range is necessary. The capacitance values ranging from 100-330 F g-1 could be reached for different asym. configurations with a capacitor voltage from 0.6-1.8 V. It is also noteworthy that such a type of ECP/CNTs composite does not need any binding substance that is an important practical advantage.

The performance of supercapacitors based on different materials with pseudocapacitive properties such as several conducting polymers (ECPs), amorphous manganese dioxide (a-MnO2), and activated carbon is reported. Composite electrodes of high resiliency and good electronic cond. were obtained by mixing the active materials with carbon nanotubes. The various limitations of all the above-mentioned materials, when used as neg. and pos. electrodes in traditional sym. systems, are shown. A successful application of ECPs and a-MnO2 in supercapacitor technologies is possible only in an asym. configuration, i.e. with electrodes of different nature for pos. and neg. polarizations. Several types of asym. capacitors were developed by combining ECPs, a-MnO2, and activated carbon and characterized in aq. electrolyte by galvanostatic charge-discharge, cyclic voltammetry, and impedance spectroscopy. The best device considering the specific energy and power is the asym. supercapacitor using a-MnO2 and poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) for the pos. and neg. electrodes, resp. It has an operating voltage of 1.8 V, which is attributed to different operating potentials of both electrodes, and good electrochem. stability in neutral aq. electrolyte. According to the voltage value, the energy d. of the asym. capacitor at a c.d. of 250 mA/g is 13.5 W h/kg, which is about ten times more than for a sym. capacitor based on PEDOT in an aq. medium. The asym. capacitor provides two times higher power than a sym. capacitor based on activated carbon in org. electrolyte, and is thus extremely promising for the development of environmentally friendly systems.

A review. Porous carbons have several advantageous properties with respect to their use in energy applications that require constrained space such as in electrode materials for supercapacitors and as solid state hydrogen stores. The attractive properties of porous carbons include, ready abundance, chem. and thermal stability, ease of processability and low framework d. Activated carbons, which are perhaps the most explored class of porous carbons, have been traditionally employed as catalyst supports or adsorbents, but lately they are increasingly being used or find potential applications in the fabrication of supercapacitors and as hydrogen storage materials. This manuscript presents the state-of-the-art with respect to the prepn. of activated carbons, with emphasis on the more interesting recent developments that allow better control or maximization of porosity, the use of cheap and readily available precursors and tailoring of morphol. This review will show that the renewed interest in the synthesis of activated carbons is matched by intensive investigations into their use in supercapacitors, where they remain the electrode materials of choice. We will also show that activated carbons have been extensively studied as hydrogen storage materials and remain a strong candidate in the search for porous materials that may enable the so-called Hydrogen Economy, wherein hydrogen is used as an energy carrier. The use of activated carbons as energy materials has in the recent past and is currently experiencing rapid growth, and this review aims to present the more significant advances.

Exceptional electrochem. behavior of carbon/iodide interface has been demonstrated and successfully used in supercapacitor application. This efficient charge storage is based on specific sorption of iodide ions as well as stable reversible redox reactions connected with various possible oxidn. states of iodine from -1 to +5. An intriguing effect of iodide ions has been obsd. for pos. electrode operating in a narrow range of potential and giving extremely high capacitance values exceeding 1840 F/g. As opposed to typical pseudocapacitance effects, which are often characterized by some diffusion limitations and obsd. only at moderate regimes, our two-electrode system can be loaded until 50 A/g supplying still 125 F/g. Amazing capacitance of carbon/iodide interface has also been confirmed during long-term cycling (over 10 000 cycles). For the first time, such an innovative electrochem. system was successfully used for supercapacitor performance. The iodide ions play a useful dual role, i.e. electrolytic soln. with a good ionic cond. as well as a source of pseudo-capacitive effects.

The mechanisms involved in the storage of energy in carbon-based supercapacitors modified by the addn. of an electrochem. active compd. (quinone/hydroquinone, Q/HQ) into the electrolyte (H2SO4) are investigated. Besides the charging of the double-layer characteristic of carbon materials, galvanostatic cycling expts. performed on each electrode revealed a battery-type behavior in the anode and a pseudocapacitive hydrogen electrosorption process in the cathode as a consequence of an asym. split of voltage between the electrodes after the incorporation of HQ. Both the hydrogen electrosorption and Q/HQ redox reactions were studied in depth from the cyclic voltammograms obtained for both electrolytes in a three-electrode cell. An outstanding specific capacitance value of 5017 F g-1 was attained by the anode due to the development of the quinoid redox reactions on its surface. Meanwhile, the cathode capacitance also increased significantly with respect to the value obtained by the supercapacitor without HQ (from 290 to 477 F g-1). As a result of the concurrence of all these mechanisms of energy storage, the energy d. of the HQ-contg. SC is significantly greater than that of the original SC (30.6 W h kg-1 vs. 10.1 W h kg-1).

Development of supercapacitors with high-energy density and high-power density is a tremendous challenge. Although the use of conductive carbon materials is promising, other methods are needed to reach high cyclability, which cannot be achieved by fully utilizing the surface-oxygen redox reactions of carbon. Here we introduce an effective strategy that utilizes Cu(2+) reduction with carbon-oxygen surface groups of the binder-free electrode in a new redox-active electrolyte. We report a 10-fold increase in the voltammetric capacitance (4,700 F g(-1)) compared with conventional electrolyte. We measured galvanostatic capacitances of 1,335 F g(-1) with a retention of 99.4% after 5,000 cycles at 60 A g(-1) in a three-electrode cell and 1,010 F g(-1) in a two-electrode cell. This improvement is attributed to the synergistic effects between surface-oxygen molecules and electrolyte ions as well as the low charge transfer resistance (0.04 Ω) of the binder-free porous electrode. Our strategy provides a versatile method for designing new energy storage devices and is promising for the development of high-performance supercapacitors for large-scale applications.

We demonstrate stable hybrid electrochem. energy storage performance of a redox-active electrolyte, namely potassium ferricyanide in aq. media in a supercapacitor-like setup. Challenging issues assocd. with such a system are a large leakage current and high self-discharge, both stemming from ion redox shuttling through the separator. The latter is effectively eliminated when using an ion exchange membrane instead of a porous separator. Other crit. factors toward the optimization of a redox-active electrolyte system, esp. electrolyte concn. and vol. of electrolyte, have been studied by electrochem. methods. Finally, excellent long-term stability is demonstrated up to 10000 charge/discharge cycles at 1.2 and 1.8 V, with a broad max. stability window of up to 1.8 V cell voltage as detd. via cyclic voltammetry. An energy capacity of 28.3 Wh/kg or 11.4 Wh/L has been obtained from such cells, taking the nonlinearity of the charge-discharge profile into account. The power performance of our cell has been detd. to be 7.1 kW/kg (ca. 2.9 kW/L or 1.2 kW/m2). These ratings are higher compared to the same cell operated in aq. sodium sulfate. This hybrid electrochem. energy storage system is believed to find a strong foothold in future advanced energy storage applications.

The incorporation of a redox-active mol. in an org. electrolyte can increase the cell voltage of a supercapacitor. The redox mol. also contributes to increasing the cell capacitance by a faradaic redox reaction, and therefore the energy d. of the supercapacitor can be significantly increased. More specifically, the addn. of redox-active decamethylferrocene in an org. electrolyte results in an ∼27-fold increase in the energy d. of C-nanotube-based supercapacitors. The resulting high energy d. (36.8 Wh/kg) stems from the increased cell voltage (1.1 V → 2.1 V) and cell capacitance (8.3 F/g → 61.3 F/g) resulting from decamethylferrocene addn. The voltage increase is assocd. with the potential of the redox species relative to the electrochem. stability window of the supporting electrolyte. These results will be useful in identifying new electrolytes for high-energy-d. supercapacitors.

A new approach for a stable polymer-based supercapacitor is presented. The polyaniline-benzoquinone supercapacitor gives simultaneously high pseudo-capacitance and unmatched cycling stability (>50,000). The increased capacitance in the polyaniline-quinone supercapacitor is attributed to the fast and reversible charge-transfer process between the polyaniline-modified electrodes and the quinones. Simultaneously, the extent of unfavorable redox processes in polyaniline is lowered - enhancing the longterm stability of the porous electrochem. active polymer. The combination of the quinone redox chem. and acid-doped conductive polymer creates a low-pH supercapacitor device which is inherently stable.

Electrochem. double-layer capacitors exhibit high power and long cycle life but have low specific energy compared with batteries, limiting applications. Redox-enhanced capacitors increase specific energy by using redox-active electrolytes that are oxidized at the pos. electrode and reduced at the neg. electrode during charging. Here we report characteristics of several redox electrolytes to illustrate operational/self-discharge mechanisms and the design rules for high performance. We discover a Me viologen (MV)/bromide electrolyte that delivers a high specific energy of ∼14 Wh kg-1 based on the mass of electrodes and electrolyte, without the use of an ion-selective membrane separator. Substituting heptyl viologen for MV increases stability, with no degrdn. over 20,000 cycles. Self-discharge is low, due to adsorption of the redox couples in the charged state to the activated carbon, and comparable to cells with inert electrolyte. An electrochem. model reproduces expts. and predicts that 30-50 Wh kg-1 is possible with optimization.

We propose a novel electrochem. capacitor (EC) utilizing an "electrolytic" charge-storage system of bromide species. The present EC cell is fabricated with 1.0 mol dm-3 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide dissolved in 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate as an electrolyte and activated carbon fiber cloths (ACFCs) as electrodes. Although such a charge-storage concept would usually be useless due to inevitable, undesirable reactions, e.g. shuttle reaction or migration of active redox species between electrodes, we attain much-enhanced capacitance with an excellent reversibility by suppressing an undesirable diffusion process. In fact, the coulombic efficiency of the present cell is over 99.7% at 100 mA g-1. The oxidn. species such as Br2 or Br3- as charge accumulators do not diffuse from a pos. electrode into the electrolyte. Moreover, the present EC cell has an excellent cycle-ability of at least 10,000 cycles.

The faradaic reactions differ at the pos. and neg. electrodes, and both reactions contribute to the large voltage dependence of the capacitance obsd. for electrochem. capacitors fabricated using EMPyr(FH)2.3F. The most probable redox reaction at the pos. electrode is the oxidn. of C accompanied by absorption of (FH)nF- or F- into the activated C species, and the reverse process. At the neg. electrode, the most probable process is the redox reaction involving the adsorption of at. H generated from (FH)nF- and the reverse process, although the redox reaction involving surface functional groups cannot be ruled out. The total capacitances of the pos. and neg. electrodes achieved for charging up to 2.5 V at 238 mA g-1 were 290 and 246 F g-1, resp. The double-layer and redox capacitance contributions to the pos. capacitance were 140 F g-1 and 150 F g-1, resp., whereas the corresponding contributions to the neg. capacitance were 130 F g-1 and 116 F g-1, resp.

Here we present redox ionic liq. supercapacitors (RILSCs) which use electrolytes made from ionic liqs. modified with an electroactive function to increase the energy d. of activated carbon electrodes via faradaic reactions. More specifically, two different ionic liqs. were made by modifying either the imidazolium cation or the bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide anion with ferrocene in order to det. the importance of the electroactive ion's polarity. The functionalization of an ionic liq. with ferrocene led to high concns. of redox moieties in the electrolyte (2.4 M) and a large max. operating voltage (2.5 V). An energy d. of up to 13.2 Wh per kg (both electrodes) was obtained which represents an 83% increase vs. the unmodified ionic liq. When the ionic liq.'s anion is modified with ferrocene, the self-discharge at the pos. electrode is fully suppressed due to the deposition of a film on the electrode. The results presented herein demonstrate that electroactive ionic liqs. constitute a promising alternative to conventional solute in solvent electrolytes found in energy storage devices, and are particularly well-suited for redox-active electrolyte supercapacitors.

Mourad, Eleonore; Coustan, Laura; Lannelongue, Pierre; Zigah, Dodzi; Mehdi, Ahmad; Vioux, Andre; Freunberger, Stefan A.; Favier, Frederic; Fontaine, Olivier

Kinetics of electrochem. reactions are several orders of magnitude slower in solids than in liqs. as a result of the much lower ion diffusivity. Yet, the solid state maximizes the d. of redox species, which is at least two orders of magnitude lower in liqs. because of soly. limitations. With regard to electrochem. energy storage devices, this leads to high-energy batteries with limited power and high-power supercapacitors with a well-known energy deficiency. For such devices the ideal system should endow the liq. state with a d. of redox species close to the solid state. Here we report an approach based on biredox ionic liqs. to achieve bulk-like redox d. at liq.-like fast kinetics. The cation and anion of these biredox ionic liqs. bear moieties that undergo very fast reversible redox reactions. As a first demonstration of their potential for high-capacity/high-rate charge storage, we used them in redox supercapacitors. These ionic liqs. are able to decouple charge storage from an ion-accessible electrode surface, by storing significant charge in the pores of the electrodes, to minimize self-discharge and leakage current as a result of retaining the redox species in the pores, and to raise working voltage due to their wide electrochem. window.

A review. This paper reviews progress that has been made in the use of Raman spectroscopy to study graphene and carbon nanotubes. These are two nanostructured forms of sp2 carbon materials that are of major current interest. These nanostructured materials have attracted particular attention because of their simplicity, small phys. size and the exciting new science they have introduced. This review focuses on each of these materials systems individually and comparatively as prototype examples of nanostructured materials. In particular, this paper discusses the power of Raman spectroscopy as a probe and a characterization tool for sp2 carbon materials, with particular emphasis given to the field of photophysics. Some coverage is also given to the close relatives of these sp2 carbon materials, namely graphite, a three-dimensional (3D) material based on the AB stacking of individual graphene layers, and carbon nanoribbons, which are one-dimensional (1D) planar structures, where the width of the ribbon is on the nanometer length scale. Carbon nanoribbons differ from carbon nanotubes is that nanoribbons have edges, whereas nanotubes have terminations only at their two ends.

The authors report on the use of 0.7 M Et4NBF4 in ADN as electrolyte in EDLCs. 0.7 M Et4NBF4 in ADN displays a wide electrochem. stability window and promising values of cond. and viscosity. Using this electrolyte it is possible to realize EDLCs with an operative voltage ≤3.75 CM-1. At RT, these high voltage EDLCs display high coulombic efficiencies, low ESRs and high specific capacitances stable for several thousands of cycles. The wide electrochem. stability of ADN contributes to preserve the integrity of the electrolyte at potentials in which other conventional org. electrolytes (e.g. ACN) are normally subject to deterioration and/or decompn. processes. Thanks to this intrinsic stability, EDLCs contg. 0.7 M Et4NBF4 ADN as electrolyte display high capacitance retention over 35,000 cycles carried out with cell voltage ≤3.5 V.

Two-dimensional (2D) carbon nanosheets have emerged as an attractive candidate for elec. double layer capacitors (EDLCs) due to their large sp. surface area, good elec. cond. and high charge mobility. However, the easy aggregation nature of nanosheets hinders rapid transport of electrolyte ions, reducing the ion-accessible area and restricting the ion transportation. Herein, we propose a template strategy for prepg. three-dimensional (3D) porous carbon nanosheets (PCNs) with an oriented and interconnected nanostructure. Zinc layered hydroxide nitrate is used as a layered template and provides a nanospace to confine the carbonization process of the org. carbon precursor (gallic acid). The unique nanostructure and large surface area of chem. activated PCNs (aPCNs) significantly shorten the ion transport length in low dimensions and improve the electrolyte wettability and ion accessible surface area for charge storage. The aPCNs exhibit excellent performance as demonstrated by their large specific capacitance (327 F g-1 at a c.d. of 0.5 A g-1), superior rate capability (retaining 60.2% at 20 A g-1) and stable cyclability. In particular, the assembled sym. device based on aPCNs delivers an energy d. as high as 10.2 W h kg-1 at a power d. of 301 W kg-1.

The restacking of reduced graphene oxide (RGO) with undesirable energy d. and power d. is still a thorny issue. In our work, we proposed a simple strategy from incorporating ionic liq. (IL) and multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) in turn to impede the RGO sheets aggregation. With synergistic effect of IL ions intercalation and MWCNTs spacers, a uniformly dispersed hierarchical pore structure was obtained. For RGO-IL-MWCNTs, a very high sp. surface area (588.7 m2 g-1) with enhanced fraction of mesopores and macropores can provide more accessible areas and pathways for charge accommodation and IL diffusion. This optimized hierarchical pore structure possesses a high specific capacity of 269.3 F g-1 (at 2 mV s-1) and a very high energy d. of 131.8 Wh kg-1 (at a power d. of 892.6 W kg-1) in pure IL electrolyte at room temp. Interestingly, this simple method probably offers excellent potential for large-scale prodn. of dispersed two-dimensional layered materials with superior performance.

The development of new brands of supercapacitors (SCs) has led to a variety of energy storage mechanisms and frequently to performance overestimation or erroneous presentation of the capacitive behavior through applying math. relations valid only for elec. double-layer capacitors (EDLCs). This paper addresses a realistic evaluation of capacitive performance and efficiency of SCs based on carbon electrodes. The presented examples of imprecise data processing include misleading information, such as seeming discharge capacitance increase during SC aging and coulombic efficiencies of 90% for SCs involving redox processes while energy efficiency is only 50%. Even in typical EDLCs, energy efficiency is 5-10% lower than coulombic efficiency.

A review. The functions and applications of electron-reservoir iron and cobalt sandwich complexes are reviewed with emphasis of the author's work using the 19-electron FeI complexes [(η5-C5R5)Fe(η6-C6Me6)], R = H or Me, the most electron-rich neutral mols. known to date and the 17-electron FeIII complex [(η5-C5Me5)Fe(η6-C6Me6)][SbCl6]2, the strongest known organometallic oxidant. A review. Electrochem. capacitors, also called supercapacitors, store energy using either ion adsorption (electrochem. double layer capacitors) or fast surface redox reactions (pseudo-capacitors). A notable improvement in performance has been achieved through recent advances in understanding charge storage mechanisms and the development of advanced nanostructured materials. The discovery that ion desolvation occurs in pores smaller than the solvated ions has led to higher capacitance for electrochem. double layer capacitors using carbon electrodes with sub-nanometer pores, and opened the door to designing high-energy d. devices using a variety of electrolytes. Combination of pseudo-capacitive nanomaterials, including oxides, nitrides and polymers, with the latest generation of nanostructured lithium electrodes has brought the energy d. of electrochem. capacitors closer to that of batteries. The use of carbon nanotubes has further advanced micro-electrochem. capacitors, enabling flexible and adaptable devices to be made. Math. modeling and simulation will be the key to success in designing tomorrow's high-energy and high-power devices.

A review with 50 refs. Electrochem. capacitors (EC) also called "supercapacitors" or "ultracapacitors" store the energy in the elec. field of the electrochem. double-layer. Use of high surface-area electrodes result in extremely large capacitance. Single cell voltage of ECs is typically limited to 1-3 V depending on the electrolyte used. Small electrochem. capacitors for low-voltage electronic applications have been com. available for many years. Different applications demanding large ECs with high voltage and improved energy and power d. are under discussion. Fundamental principles, performance, characteristics, present and future applications of electrochem. capacitors are presented in this communication.

The science and technol. of ultracapacitors are reviewed, with 24 refs., for a no. of electrode materials, including carbon, mixed metal oxides, and conducting polymers. More work has been done using microporous carbons than with the other materials and most of the com. available devices use carbon electrodes and an org. electrolytes. The energy d. of these devices is 3-5 Wh/kg with a power d. of 300-500 W/kg for high efficiency (90-95%) charge/discharges. Projections of future developments using carbon indicate that energy densities of 10 Wh/kg or higher are likely with power densities of 1-2 kW/kg. A key problem in the fabrication of these advanced devices is the bonding of the thin electrodes to a current collector such that the contact resistance is less than 0.1 Ω cm2. Special attention is given in the paper to comparing the power d. characteristics of ultracapacitors and batteries. The comparisons should be made at the same charge/discharge efficiency.

The increasing interest in energy storage for the grid can be attributed to multiple factors, including the capital costs of managing peak demands, the investments needed for grid reliability, and the integration of renewable energy sources. A review. Supercapacitors are currently attracting intensive attention because they can provide energy d. by orders of magnitude higher than dielec. capacitors, greater power d., and longer cycling ability than batteries. The main challenge for supercapacitors is to develop them with high energy d. that is close to that of a current rechargeable battery, while maintaining their inherent characteristics of high power and long cycling life. Consequently, much research has been devoted to enhance the performance of supercapacitors by either maximizing the specific capacitance and/or increasing the cell voltage. The latest advances in the exploration and development of new supercapacitor systems and related electrode materials are highlighted. Also, the prospects and challenges in practical application are analyzed, aiming to give deep insights into the material science and electrochem. fields.

A review. In recent years, tremendous research effort has been aimed at increasing the energy d. of supercapacitors without sacrificing high power capability so that they reach the levels achieved in batteries and at lowering fabrication costs. For this purpose, two important problems have to be solved: first, it is crit. to develop ways to design high performance electrode materials for supercapacitors; second, it is necessary to achieve controllably assembled supercapacitor types (such as sym. capacitors including double-layer and pseudo-capacitors, asym. capacitors, and Li-ion capacitors). The explosive growth of research in this field makes this review timely. Recent progress in the research and development of high performance electrode materials and high-energy supercapacitors is summarized. Several key issues for improving the energy densities of supercapacitors and some mutual relationships among various effecting parameters are reviewed, and challenges and perspectives in this exciting field are also discussed. This provides fundamental insight into supercapacitors and offers an important guideline for future design of advanced next-generation supercapacitors for industrial and consumer applications.

A review. Currently, supercapacitors (SCs) are a promising field in the area of energy storage devices. In the last few decades, different types of C based materials with suitable surface modifications, metal oxides, metal hydroxides, conducting polymers and their various composites have been used as electrodes to improve the energy performance of SCs. Different technologies like asym. and hybrid systems have also been introduced. Another alternative approach was proposed recently by a few research groups, wherein electrolytes (liq. and polymer) can enhance the performance of the SCs via redox reactions at the electrode-electrolyte interface, by introducing redox additives or mediators in the electrolytes. The main advantage of this new technique is its simple and safe prepn. method, along with cost effectiveness compared to the prepn. of some active electrode materials. Hence it is believed that identification of suitable redox additives or species in electrolytes will be of interest in the field of SCs in the coming years.

A review. Most methods for improving supercapacitor performance are based on developments of electrode materials to optimally exploit their storage mechanisms, namely elec. double layer capacitance and pseudocapacitance. In such cases, the electrolyte is supposed to be electrochem. as inert as possible so that a wide potential window can be achieved. Interestingly, in recent years, there has been a growing interest in the investigation of supercapacitors with an electrolyte that can offer redox activity. Such redox electrolytes have been shown to offer increased charge storage capacity, and possibly other benefits. There are however some confusions, for example, on the nature of contributions of the redox electrolyte to the increased storage capacity in comparison with pseudocapacitance, or by expression of the overall increased charge storage capacity as capacitance. This report intends to provide a brief but crit. review on the pros and cons of the application of such redox electrolytes in supercapacitors, and to advocate development of the relevant research into a new electrochem. energy storage device in parallel with, but not the same as that of supercapacitors.

A review. Supercapacitors have attracted intense attention due to their great potential to meet the demand of both high energy d. and power d. in many advanced technologies. Various carbon-based nanocomposites are currently pursued as supercapacitor electrodes because of the synergistic effect between carbon (high power d.) and pseudo-capacitive nanomaterials (high energy d.). This feature article aims to review most recent progress on 3D (3D) carbon based nanostructures for advanced supercapacitor applications in view of their structural intertwinement which not only create the desired hierarchical porous channels, but also possess higher elec. cond. and better structural mech. stability. The carbon nanostructures comprise of CNTs-based networks, graphene-based architectures, hierarchical porous carbon-based nanostructures and other even more complex carbon-based 3D configurations. Their advantages and disadvantages are compared and summarized based on the results published in the literature. In addn., we also discuss and view the ongoing trends in materials development for advanced supercapacitors.

A review. Supercapacitor electrodes and devices that use conducting polymers are envisaged to bridge the gap between existing C-based supercapacitors and batteries to form units of intermediate specific energy. This review looks at the major conducting polymer materials, namely, polyaniline, polypyrrole, polythiophene and derivs. of polythiophene, as well as composites of these materials with C nanotubes and inorg. battery materials. Various treatments of the conducting polymer materials to improve their properties are considered and comparisons are made with other supercapacitor materials such as C and with inorg. battery materials. Conducting polymers are pseudo-capacitive materials, which means that the bulk of the material undergoes a fast redox reaction to provide the capacitive response and they exhibit superior specific energies to the C-based supercapacitors (double-layer capacitors). In general conducting polymers are more conductive than the inorg. battery materials and consequently have greater power capability. On the downside, conducting polymers swell and contract substantially on charge and discharge, resp. Consequently, cycle-life is poor compared with C-based supercapacitors which generally only charge via adsorption and desorption of (giving typically a few thousand cycles for conducting polymers compared with >500,000 cycles for C-based devices).

A review of recent advances in strategies for advanced metal oxide-based hybrid nanostructure design, with the focus on the binder-free film/array electrodes. Metal oxide nanostructures are promising electrode materials for lithium-ion batteries and supercapacitors because of their high specific capacity/capacitance, typically 2-3 times higher than that of the carbon/graphite-based materials. These binder-free electrodes, with the integration of unique merits of each component, can provide larger electrochem. active surface area, faster electron transport and superior ion diffusion, thus leading to substantially improved cycling and rate performance. However, their cycling stability and rate performance still cannot meet the requirements of practical applications. Several recently emerged concepts of using ordered nanostructure arrays, synergetic core-shell structures, nanostructured current collectors, and flexible paper/textile electrodes are highlighted, pointing out advantages and challenges where appropriate. Some future electrode design trends and directions are also discussed.

A review with 54 refs. The electrochem. storage of energy in various carbon materials (activated carbons, aerogels, xerogels, nanostructures) used as capacitor electrodes is considered. Different types of capacitors with a pure electrostatic attraction and/or pseudocapacitance effects are presented. Their performance in various electrolytes is studied taking into account the different range of operating voltage (1 V for aq. and 3 V for aprotic solns.). Trials are undertaken for estg. the role of micro and mesopores during charging the elec. double layer in both kinds of electrolytic solns. for which the elec. cond. and the size of solvated ions are different. The effect of pseudocapacitance for maximizing the total capacitance is esp. documented. Carbons chem. modified by a strong oxidn. treatment represent a very well defined region of pseudocapacitance properties due to the Faradaic redox reactions of their rich surface functionality. Conducting polymers (polyaniline, polypyrrole, polythiophene derivs.) and oxidized metallic particles (Ru, Mn, Co,...) deposited on the carbons also participate in the enhancement of the final capacity through fast faradaic pseudocapacitance effects. Evaluation of capacitor performance by different techniques, e.g. voltammetry, impedance spectroscopy, charge/discharge characteristics is also discussed.

We demonstrate the high performance of supercapacitors fabricated with vertically aligned carbon nanotubes and nonaq. electrolytes such as ionic liqs. and conventional org. electrolytes. Specific capacitance, max. power and energy d. of the supercapacitor measured in ionic liq. were ∼75 F g-1, ∼987 kW kg-1 and ∼27 W h kg-1, resp. The high power performance was consistently indicated by a fast relaxation time const. of 0.2 s. In addn., electrochem. oxidn. of the carbon nanotubes improved the specific capacitance (∼58 F g-1) and energy d. (∼53 W h kg-1). Both high power and energy d. could be attributed to the fast ion transport realized by the alignment of carbon nanotubes and the wide operational voltage defined by the ionic liq. The demonstrated carbon-nanotube- and nonaq.-electrolyte-based supercapacitors show great potential for the development of high-performance energy storage devices.

A review. This tutorial review provides a brief summary of recent research progress on carbon-based electrode materials for supercapacitors, as well as the importance of electrolytes in the development of supercapacitor technol. The basic principles of supercapacitors, the characteristics and performances of various nanostructured carbon-based electrode materials are discussed. Aq. and nonaq. electrolyte solns. used in supercapacitors are compared. The trend on future development of high-power and high-energy supercapacitors is analyzed.

Compn. design and morphol. control can lead to high performance electrode materials for energy storage devices. In this work a graphene/porous Fe2O3 nanocomposite anode material is fabricated via a template-assisted nanocasting process. This nanocomposite consists of graphene scaffold with high electronic cond. and interconnected Fe2O3 with porous structure, thus exposing ample active sites for redox reactions and offering sufficient contacts with the electrolyte. Owing to these morphol. advantages, the nanocomposite outperforms nearly all the reported Fe-based anode materials by delivering a high specific capacitance of 1095 F g-1 at a c.d. of 3 A g-1. In addn., the material shows great rate capability and good cycling stability. Asym. supercapacitors are fabricated by assembling the graphene/porous Fe2O3 nanocomposite (as the anode material) with a CoNi-layered double hydroxide/carbon nanotube composite (as the cathode material). The devices exhibit high energy and power densities of 98.0 W h kg-1 and 22,826 W kg-1, which are among the best performances reported to date for asym. supercapacitors.

Supercapacitors based on conducting polymers/nanotubes composites
Frackowiak, E.; Khomenko, V.; Jurewicz, K.; Lota, K.; Beguin, F.

Three types of elec. conducting polymers (ECPs), i.e. polyaniline (PANI), polypyrrole (PPy) and poly-(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) were tested as supercapacitor electrode materials in the form of composites with multiwalled C nanotubes (CNTs). The energy storage in such a type of composite combines an electrostatic attraction as well as quick faradaic processes called pseudo-capacitance. C nanotubes play the role of a perfect backbone for a homogeneous distribution of ECP in the composite. It is well known that pure conducting polymers are mech. weak, hence, the carbon nanotubes preserve the ECP active material from mech. changes (shrinkage and breaking) during long cycling. Apart of excellent conducting and mech. properties, the presence of nanotubes improves also the charge transfer that enables a high charge/discharge rate. For an optimal use of ECPs in electrochem. capacitors, a special electrode compn. with ≈20 wt.% of CNTs and a careful selection of the potential range is necessary. The capacitance values ranging from 100-330 F g-1 could be reached for different asym. configurations with a capacitor voltage from 0.6-1.8 V. It is also noteworthy that such a type of ECP/CNTs composite does not need any binding substance that is an important practical advantage.

The performance of supercapacitors based on different materials with pseudocapacitive properties such as several conducting polymers (ECPs), amorphous manganese dioxide (a-MnO2), and activated carbon is reported. Composite electrodes of high resiliency and good electronic cond. were obtained by mixing the active materials with carbon nanotubes. The various limitations of all the above-mentioned materials, when used as neg. and pos. electrodes in traditional sym. systems, are shown. A successful application of ECPs and a-MnO2 in supercapacitor technologies is possible only in an asym. configuration, i.e. with electrodes of different nature for pos. and neg. polarizations. Several types of asym. capacitors were developed by combining ECPs, a-MnO2, and activated carbon and characterized in aq. electrolyte by galvanostatic charge-discharge, cyclic voltammetry, and impedance spectroscopy. The best device considering the specific energy and power is the asym. supercapacitor using a-MnO2 and poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) for the pos. and neg. electrodes, resp. It has an operating voltage of 1.8 V, which is attributed to different operating potentials of both electrodes, and good electrochem. stability in neutral aq. electrolyte. According to the voltage value, the energy d. of the asym. capacitor at a c.d. of 250 mA/g is 13.5 W h/kg, which is about ten times more than for a sym. capacitor based on PEDOT in an aq. medium. The asym. capacitor provides two times higher power than a sym. capacitor based on activated carbon in org. electrolyte, and is thus extremely promising for the development of environmentally friendly systems.

Energy storage applications of activated carbons: supercapacitors and hydrogen storage
